choices.text: Coronary Artery Disease
Her BMI is below the Cut off for Surgery
Capable of Understanding Lifestyle Changes
Severe Depression

questions.text: A 35 years old female patient has a BMI of 36 kg/m2. She has multiple comorbidities and hence presented to the bariatric surgeon for surgical options to lose weight. Which of the below parameters will make her unfit for surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Severe Depression

 

Option D: Severe depression can impact a patient's ability to adhere to the necessary lifestyle changes post-surgery and could impair the patient's capacity to give informed consent, making her unfit for surgery until the depression is adequately treated.

 

The patient should be psychologically stable to undergo bariatric surgery. Psychological instability makes the patient incapable of understanding the implication of the surgery. Uncontrolled psychiatric illness is a contra-indication for surgery.

 

 

*NICE updated: Its guidance and lowered the BMI threshold to 30 kg/m2 for recent-onset type 2 diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

Let's evaluate all the options to identify which parameter would make a 35-year-old female patient with a BMI of 36 kg/m^2 unfit for bariatric surgery:

 

Option A. Coronary artery disease is a significant comorbidity that needs to be well-managed before bariatric surgery, but it does not necessarily make a patient unfit for surgery if optimized. In fact, it is one of the co-morbidities which can be considered as an indication.

 

Option B. A BMI below the cut-off for surgery could make a patient ineligible for bariatric surgery. However, a BMI of 36 kg/m^2 is above the typical cut-off of 35 kg/m^2 with comorbidities or 40 kg/m^2 without comorbidities.

 

Option C. Being capable of understanding lifestyle changes is a necessary criterion for suitability for bariatric surgery, not a disqualifying one.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe depression can make a patient unfit for bariatric surgery because it may affect their ability to understand and comply with the significant lifestyle changes required postoperatively.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed., Pg 1184

choices.text: Roux-en-Y Gastrojejunostomy
Sleeve Gastrectomy
Pyloric Exclusion with Gastrojejunostomy
Laparoscopic Gastric Banding

questions.text: Which of the following is not a bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pyloric Exclusion with Gastrojejunostomy

 

Option C: Pyloric exclusion with gastrojejunostomy is a surgical procedure used in the repair of duodenal and pancreatic injuries. It is not intended for weight loss and thus not classified as a bariatric surgery.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Roux-en-Y gastrojejunostomy is a common form of bariatric surgery that is both restrictive and malabsorptive. It involves creating a small stomach pouch and connecting it directly to the jejunum.

 

Option B. Sleeve gastrectomy is a restrictive bariatric surgery where a portion of the stomach is removed, leaving a smaller, tube-shaped stomach.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic gastric banding is a restrictive bariatric surgery that involves placing an adjustable band around the upper portion of the stomach to create a small stomach pouch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyloric exclusion with gastrojejunostomy is not a bariatric surgery; it is a technique used to repair duodenal and pancreatic injuries. Bariatric surgeries are primarily aimed at weight loss and include restrictive, malabsorptive, combined procedures, and endoscopic bariatric procedures.

 

Types of Bariatric procedures:

 

  1. Restrictive: Where stomach is reduced in size à reduction in meal size à lower calorie intake à Weight loss.

 

Examples: Sleeve gastrectomy, adjustable gastric band

 

  1. Malabsorptive: Where segment of intestine is bypassed à less absorptive area à Lesser absorption of food à weight loss.

 

Examples: Biliopancreatic diversion/Duodenal switch, Mini-gastric bypass

 

  1. Combined: Where both of above effects are applicable.

 

Example: Roux-en-Y gastric bypass

 

  1. Endoscopic bariatric procedures: non-surgical, purely by endoscopic approach

 

Example: Gastric balloon, Endoscopic gastroplasty (principally same as restrictive procedures)

 

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1185

choices.text: Laparoscopic adjustable Gastric Banding
Laparoscopic Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass
Laparoscopic Sleeve Gastrectomy
Both A and B

questions.text: According to the principles of bariatric surgery, which of the following is/are considered as reversible bariatric surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Both A and B

 

Option A. Laparoscopic Adjustable Gastric Banding (LAGB) involves placing a band around the upper portion of the stomach to create a small pouch. It is designed to be adjustable and is considered reversible because the band can be removed if necessary.

 

Option B. Laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is a more complex surgery that changes the way food travels through the stomach and small intestine. The procedure can be reversed into normal anatomy if deemed necessary.

 

Explanation:

 

Option C. Laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy involves removing a portion of the stomach to create a smaller, sleeve-shaped stomach. This procedure is not considered reversible because the removed portion of the stomach cannot be replaced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic adjustable gastric banding and RYGB considered a reversible bariatric surgery because the band can be removed or adjusted postoperatively, while the Roux-en-Y configuration can be reversed, unlike other forms of bariatric surgery that permanently alter the stomach or digestive tract.

 

Complications of LAGB include:

 

  • Prolapse / Slippage (most common)
  • Band erosion of the stomach wall and rupture
  • Increased risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism (highest risk within 1 month of surgery), managed with early ambulation, pressure stockings and LMWH.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed Pg 1187

choices.text: Left Internal Mammary Artery
Great Saphenous Vein
Right Internal Mammary Artery
Left Radial Artery Graft

questions.text: In Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery, conduit of choice for grafting the Left anterior descending coronary artery occlusion is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left Internal Mammary Artery

 

Option A: The Left Internal Mammary Artery (LIMA) is the preferred conduit for grafting the LAD due to its superior long-term patency rates and reduced risk of atherosclerosis.

 

Ideal graft for LAD is - Left Internal Mammary Artery

 

MC used venous graft in Coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery is – Great saphenous vein graft. The long saphenous vein is the most commonly used venous conduit as it is straightforward to harvest, provides good length and is easy to handle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The Great saphenous vein, while commonly used in CABG for its ease of harvest and length, is more prone to atherosclerosis and has a lower long-term patency rate compared to arterial grafts.

 

Option C. The Right internal mammary artery is also a good option for grafting and can be used for the LAD, but the LIMA is preferred because of its closer proximity and direct course to the LAD.

 

Option D. The Left radial artery graft can be used for coronary bypass; however, it is generally reserved for situations where the internal mammary arteries are not usable or in multiple arterial grafting strategies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is the conduit of choice for grafting the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery occlusion in CABG surgery due to its excellent long-term patency and proximity to the LAD.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 950

choices.text: Lung Transplant
Vascular Tumour Excision
CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Graft)
IVC filter insertion in Pulmonary Thromboembolism

questions.text: Which of these is not an indication of Cardiopulmonary bypass?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IVC filter insertion in Pulmonary Thromboembolism

 

Option D: IVC filter insertion in pulmonary thromboembolism is performed to prevent further pulmonary emboli from reaching the pulmonary circulation. It does not typically require cardiopulmonary bypass, as it can be done percutaneously and does not involve open surgery.

 

Indications of Cardiopulmonary bypass:

 

  1. Open heart surgery: CABG/valve replacement
  2. Lung transplant
  3. Vascular tumour excision
  4. Pulmonary embolism
  5. Profound hypothermia

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lung transplant surgery is a complex procedure that often requires cardiopulmonary bypass to maintain circulation and oxygenation while the diseased lungs are replaced.

 

Option B. Vascular tumor excision can necessitate the use of cardiopulmonary bypass, especially if the tumor is within or adjacent to the heart or great vessels, to maintain blood flow and organ perfusion during the surgery.

 

Option C. Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is a common indication for cardiopulmonary bypass as it allows the heart to be still while bypasses are created to route blood around clogged arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The insertion of an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter in the case of pulmonary thromboembolism is not an indication for cardiopulmonary bypass, as it is a minimally invasive procedure that does not necessitate the cessation of heart and lung function.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 945

choices.text: ECMO (Extra-Corporeal Membrane Oxygenation)
IABP (Intra-Aortic Balloon Pump)
VAD (Ventricular Assist Devices)
All of the above

questions.text: Which of these are mechanical support devices for low cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Option D: All of the above options are mechanical support devices used for low cardiac output. Each has a specific role and may be chosen based on the individual patient's condition and the underlying cause of their heart failure.

 

If low cardiac output persists despite inotropic support, the heart may require mechanical support while it recovers its function. Mechanical support can be achieved using an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP), ventricular assist device (VAD) or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ECMO, or Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation, is a device that provides both cardiac and respiratory support to patients whose heart and lungs are so severely diseased or damaged that they can no longer serve their function adequately. It does the function of oxygenation of blood.

 

Option B. The IABP, or Intra-aortic Balloon Pump, is a mechanical device that increases myocardial oxygen perfusion and simultaneously increases cardiac output. It is inserted into the aorta and helps the heart by reducing afterload and increasing blood flow to the coronary arteries.

 

Option C. VADs, or Ventricular Assist Devices, are mechanical pumps that are used to support heart function and blood flow in individuals with refractory heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of persistent low cardiac output that does not respond to inotropic support, mechanical support devices such as ECMO, IABP, and VADs may be employed to aid heart function.

 

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 952

choices.text: Surgical Repair
Endovascular Stenting
Conservative Management
Both A and B

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with h/o atherosclerosis comes to the hospital with sudden onset chest pain that mimics angina. The pain radiates to interscapular region. A CT thoracic angiography shows an aortic dissection involving the descending aorta alone, classified as Stanford class B. What would be the preferred treatment for the same?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endovascular Stenting

 

Option B: Endovascular stenting is the preferred treatment for Stanford Class B aortic dissections, where the ascending aorta is not involved. This minimally invasive procedure reduces the risk of the dissection propagating or rupturing.

 

Aortic Dissection

 

  • Tear in intima of aorta
  • Blood while flowing with high force can tear layers, blood flows between those layers and enters sub-epithelial plane
  • MC site – ascending aorta
  • The DeBakey classification is based on the pattern of dissection, whereas the Stanford classification is based on whether the ascending aorta is involved

 

STANFORD CLASSIFICATION

 

  • STANFORD A: ASCENDING AORTA INVOLVED
  • STANFORD B: ASCENDING AORTA NOT INVOLVED

 

Treatment of Aortic dissection:

 

 FIRST STEP: LOWER THE BP THEN TREAT THE DISSECTION BY:

 

  • TYPE A: SURGICAL
  • TYPE B: ENDOVASCULAR STENTING

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Surgical repair is typically indicated for aortic dissections involving the ascending aorta (Stanford Class A) due to the higher risk of lethal complications such as rupture into the pericardial space, leading to cardiac tamponade.

 

Option C. Conservative management, including blood pressure control, may be appropriate for cases of aortic dissection where surgical or endovascular intervention is not immediately indicated or if the patient has comorbid conditions that increase the risk of surgical procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended treatment for a Stanford Class B aortic dissection, which does not involve the ascending aorta, is endovascular stenting, following initial blood pressure management.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 970

choices.text: Sleeve Gastrectomy
Gastric Banding
Roux en Y Gastric Bypass
Mini-Gastric Bypass

questions.text: A morbidly obese patient fitting the NICE criteria arrives at your OPD to evaluate the surgical options for her weight reduction. Which is the most commonly done surgical procedure in bariatric today?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sleeve Gastrectomy

 

Option A: Sleeve gastrectomy is currently one of the most commonly performed bariatric procedures. It reduces the size of the stomach, leading to a lower calorie intake and subsequent weight loss. It is considered less challenging than other procedures and has a lower risk of internal hernias.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Gastric banding was once a popular bariatric surgery, but its frequency has decreased due to the higher prevalence and success rates of other procedures like the sleeve gastrectomy.

 

Option C. Roux en y gastric bypass is a procedure that involves creating a small pouch from the stomach and connecting it directly to the small intestine. Although it is a common and effective procedure, it is more complex than sleeve gastrectomy and carries a higher risk of complications like internal hernias.

 

Option D. Mini-gastric bypass is a variation of the traditional gastric bypass but has not surpassed the sleeve gastrectomy in frequency of performance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly done surgical procedure in bariatrics today due to its simplicity relative to other options and its effectiveness in weight loss.

 

Sleeve gastrectomy is a type of restrictive surgery which works on the following principle:

 

Where stomach is reduced in size (by creating a vertical sleeve, resecting much of the greater curvature) → reduction in meal size → lower calorie intake → Weight loss. It is the most common surgery done today, since it is less challenging and there is reduction in number of internal hernias.

 

 

 

Complications of sleeve gastrectomy:

 

  • Bleed from staple line
  • Leakage from staple line at angle of His (upper end)
  • GERD in the long term

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1186

choices.text: Narrowing of Gastro-Jejunostomy
Internal Hernia
Leak from Staple Line
Pulmonary Embolism

questions.text: A 45 years old lady underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass 2 years ago. She comes to the emergency with sudden onset abdominal pain and vomiting. She is afebrile. Abdomen exam shows vague diffuse tenderness. An urgent CECT abdomen is done, which shows dilated small bowel loops. Which of these is a dangerous late complication in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal Hernia

 

Option B: Internal hernia is a serious late complication of gastric bypass surgery. It can occur as a patient loses weight and spaces where the intestine can herniate open up. This can lead to bowel obstruction, which may manifest as dilated bowel loops on imaging, and it requires prompt surgical intervention.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Narrowing of gastro-jejunostomy can cause obstruction and vomiting but would typically not lead to diffuse abdominal tenderness and is more of an early complication post-surgery.

 

Option C. A leak from the staple line is generally an early postoperative complication and would typically present with signs of infection such as fever, which is not mentioned in this scenario.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism could cause sudden onset symptoms but would not explain the finding of dilated small bowel loops on the CECT abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An internal hernia is a dangerous late complication after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass that can present with symptoms of bowel obstruction and requires high priority for laparoscopic investigation, even in the face of normal imaging studies.

 

  • Internal hernias develop as weight is lost and hernia spaces open up after gastric bypass.
  • CT scanning has a high rate of false negatives for internal hernia, so anyone presenting with severe, cramping abdominal pain 2–3 years after surgery needs to be high priority for investigation by laparoscopy.
  • Closure of the internal hernia spaces is now standard of care in Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

 

Complications of Bariatric Surgery:

 

  1. Related to Surgery: Postoperative bleed, post-operative staple line leak, internal hernia, band erosion.
  2. Related to Obesity: Deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism (most common cause of death), respiratory failure.
  3. Related to Reduced Food Intake/Malabsorption: Hypo-proteinemia, anemia, vitamin deficiencies (Vit B12/Vit D etc.).

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1188-89

choices.text: Gastric Band
Roux en Y Gastric Bypass
Sleeve Gastrectomy
Duodenal Switch

questions.text: Which of these bariatric procedures leads to maximum weight loss and nutritional deficiencies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duodenal Switch

 

Option D: Duodenal switch, also known as biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS), is a procedure that includes both restrictive and malabsorptive components. It typically results in greater weight loss than other bariatric procedures and also carries a higher risk of nutritional deficiencies due to the significant bypass of the small intestine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gastric band is a restrictive bariatric procedure that reduces food intake by creating a small pouch at the top of the stomach. It generally results in moderate weight loss and has a lower risk of nutritional deficiencies compared to more invasive surgeries.

 

Option B. Roux en Y gastric bypass is a combination of restrictive and malabsorptive procedures and can lead to significant weight loss and nutritional deficiencies, but not typically to the extent seen with more malabsorptive procedures.

 

Option C. Sleeve gastrectomy is mainly a restrictive procedure that removes a portion of the stomach. It can lead to substantial weight loss, but because there is no bypass of the intestines, it generally causes fewer nutritional deficiencies than malabsorptive procedures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The duodenal switch bariatric procedure leads to the most significant weight loss and the highest risk of nutritional deficiencies due to its extensive malabsorptive component.

 

 

Note: % EWL= Excess Weight Loss

 

Ref: Bailey and Love, 28th Ed. Pg 1185.

choices.text: Sleeve Gastrectomy- GERD is a long term Complication
Sleeve Gastrectomy- Leak from Upper Staple Line is the “Achilles Heel”
Internal Hernia- Seen after Roux en Y gastric bypass
Gastric Band- Protein Energy Malnutrition

questions.text: Identify the mismatch in the bariatric procedures and associated complications:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gastric band- Protein Energy Malnutrition

 

Option D: This statement is a mismatch. Protein-energy malnutrition is not typically associated with gastric banding. Gastric banding is more commonly associated with complications such as band slippage, erosion, or mechanical issues rather than nutritional deficiencies. Protein energy malnutrition is typically seen after malabsorptive procedures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This statement is accurate. Sleeve gastrectomy may lead to the development or exacerbation of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) as a long-term complication.

 

Option B. This statement is accurate. One of the potential complications of sleeve gastrectomy is a leak from the upper staple line. The staple line is a vulnerable area where leakage can occur. Patients are typically in hospital for months and need multiple reinterventions, including any of: endoscopic interventions (stenting, endoscopic vacuum therapy), making a controlled fistula, conversion to gastric bypass and fistula enterostomy.

 

Option C. This statement is accurate. Internal hernias are a known complication after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, through the Peterson space.

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1188.
